org.apache.plc4x.java.examples.helloopm

Class HelloOpm

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.apache.plc4x.java.examples.helloopm.HelloOpm

  • public class HelloOpm
extends Object
    This Example shows how to use OPM from plc4j via the @PlcEntityManager. A @PooledPlcDriverManager is used to optimize the acces and to allow for automatic reconnection. The PlcEntityManager is similar to JPAs EntityManager. The "connected" Entity (shootCounter) can be kept and passed around and stays connected in the sense that all calls to a getter are forwared to the PLC. Finally, one can disconnect the Entity. This MT works against Tims S7 in NÃ¼rtingen. Thus, parameters have to be tuned possibly to get "good" values.
    Author:
    julian Created by julian on 31.10.18

      • main

      • readValueFromPlcUsingConnectedEntity

        public void readValueFromPlcUsingConnectedEntity()
                                          throws OPMException
        The PlcEntityManager.connect(Class, String) method returns a "connected" Entity, i.e., a proxy Object. Whenever a getter is called on the Proxy object (whose Field Variable is annotated with @PlcEntity a call to the PLC is made to fetch the value. If another method is called on the Entity all Fields are feched from the Plc first, and then the method is invoked.
        Throws:
        OPMException

      • readValueFromPlcUsingRead

        public void readValueFromPlcUsingRead()
                               throws OPMException
        The PlcEntityManager.read(Class, String) method fetches all fields annotated with @PlcField once and injects them in the new instance. After the constructing this is a regular POJO with no fancy functionality.
        Throws:
        OPMException
